courseWork.title: [Act6] Friction and Normal Forces
courseWork.description: For your sixth and final activity for this semester, we will revisit the concepts of friction and normal force and see how these two constitute a single contact force, which would explain how they are related with each other. Attached in this posting is the lab material with the worksheet and the applet for the simulation (downloadable). You may annotate your answers directly in the pdf file or write them in a separate sheet. Submit your work with the format: SURNAME_Act6.pdf (or .jpg when scanned). If you have a question or find any inconsistencies in the lab material, please inform me by sending a message or commenting down below. Thank you!

If you have a question or find any inconsistencies in the lab material, please inform me by sending a message or commenting down below. Thank you!

courseWork.title: [Act5] Newton's Laws of Motion
courseWork.description:
For your fifth activity, you will get to test your understanding on the three laws of motion that we've discussed in the lecture course. Hopefully, by exploring the simulation, you can see how forces affect the motion of objects in real time. Attached in this posting is the lab material with the worksheet and the applet for the simulation (downloadable). You may annotate your answers directly in the pdf file or write them in a separate sheet. Submit your work with the format: SURNAME_Act5.pdf (or .jpg when scanned). If you have a question or find any inconsistencies in the lab material, please inform me by sending a message. Thank you!

NOTE: Please don't forget to complete Part 3 of the worksheet!

courseWork.title: [Act4] Projectile Motion
courseWork.description:
For your next activity, you will combine what you've learned in straight line horizontal and free-fall motion to understand how projectiles move. Attached in this posting is the lab material with the worksheet and the applet for the simulation. You may annotate your answers directly in the pdf file or write them in a separate sheet. Submit your work with the format: SURNAME_Act4.pdf (or .jpg when scanned). If you have a question or find any inconsistencies in the lab material, please inform me by sending a message. Thank you!

P.S. This activity is assigned and will be collected earlier than usual.

courseWork.title: [Act3] Freely-falling Bodies
courseWork.description: For your next activity, you will investigate how a falling object accelerates under the influence of gravity. Attached in this posting is the lab material with the worksheet and the applet for the simulation. You may annotate your answers directly in the pdf file or write them in a separate sheet. Submit your work with the format: SURNAME_Act3.pdf (or .jpg when scanned). If you have a question or find any inconsistencies in the lab material, please inform me by sending a message. Thank you!

courseWork.title: [Act2] Vector Components and Vector Addition
courseWork.description:
Our second activity is all about vectors and vector addition. Vectors are quantities which have both a magnitude (amount, extent, etc.) and a direction. (Some examples of vector quantities include velocity, acceleration, force, and momentum.) The latter makes addition of these quantities less straightforward than algebraic, and requires [basic] trigonometric principles to arrive at a result known as a resultant/net vector.

You may annotate your answers directly onto the pdf file or you may also write them on a separate sheet -- handwritten (then photographed/scanned) or typed. Please name your submitted file as SURNAME_Act2.pdf (or .jpg if you're handing in a photo). The official deadline for turning over your completed work is next Thursday, 31 March 2021 at 09:00. For any questions, concerns, or inconsistencies that you find in the document, please comment down below or send me an email. Thank you!

Note:
1) For Part II (Addition of Vectors),  you don't have to have the exact measurements as with the one given in the problem, since the simulation has limited precision. Just make sure that the vectors that you draw in the simulation will be the ones you'll use in your calculations for comparison.

courseWork.title: [Act1] Measurements, Significant Figures, and Graphs
courseWork.description:
This is the first activity for Physics 81.1, which involves measurements and how they are reported. It is recommended that you go over the written pre-lab lecture material before answering the Worksheet. You may annotate your answers directly onto the pdf file or you may also write them on a separate sheet -- handwritten (then photographed/scanned) or typed. Please name your submitted file as SURNAME_Act1.pdf (or .jpg if you're handing in a photo). The official deadline for turning over your completed work is next Thursday, 24 March 2021 at 09:00. For any questions or concerns, please comment down below or send me an email.


CORRECTIONS:
1) In the Worksheet, the Vernier scale for both items has a graduation size of 0.005 cm or 0.5 mm. For the cylindrical pipe, the first value should be for the height of the cylinder. This will read: "a height of 5.80 cm, and a diameter of 6.454 mm".
2) In Practice Problem II (item c) in the Worksheet, use 6.890 mm as the width of the rectangle instead of 6.980 mm.
